page.title: 07THE STRUCTURE OF HOUSES
page.content: Houses built in the 60's and 70's,i.e.Forestdale, are considerably smaller than those in Addington village.The building land is so scarce now that developers want to build as many dwellings as possible in the space available.This has led to the building of many flats,(i.e.Pennycroft on Forestdale),maisonettes and terraced houses in the newer parts of the area. But methods of building have changed timber and reinforced concrete are used much more widely in the construction of modern homes on the New Addington and Forestdale estates, these ways of building now allow larger areas of glass,therefore making the buildings much lighter inside. Some good examples of these modern methods of building can be found on Forestdale and New Addington.
